question: I'm not too late, am I, dear? Hello, darling, Alma Preston, how are you today?
answer: Thanks for coming, Ms. Preston, I'm Debbie Bartle. Do we have your check yet? Loretta pulls a Mont Blanc pen and a checkbook from her bag.

question: No, honey, I don't think you do, we just got in last night from our place in Barbados -- how much is it?
answer: Five hundred a person. Barbados?

question: Yes, we're just down the beach from Mick Jagger and Jerry. You wouldn't turn down a couple of thousand, would you? A pleased smile from Debbie. Loretta opens the check- book, flashing the immense RING in front of Debbie.
answer: Um, that's a lovely ring.

question: Oh, thank you. I thought it might be a little gaudy...who should I make this out to?
answer: Johnson for Congress. It's not gaudy, it's just...nice and big.

question: That's my Carlos...I can't even look in a store window. We're walking down this street in Rio, we pass a jewelry store...I didn't even turn my head and he's in the shop... ...$250,000. I said it's crazy... but you know Carlos.
answer: I wish I did. ON Tommy watching Loretta. A Guest standing just behind Tommy -- wearing MRS. ZEKE BRIDGES name tag -- watches JEFF JOHNSON gladhand the room robustly.

question: The sum' bitch looks terrific. How about taking our orders, son?
answer: Absolutely my friend! How can I pleasure you?

question: Bourbon straight up and a Perrier rocks for the lady.
answer: Ah! Fire and ice! Wonderful! But may I suggest you make that a double sir? After all, so many guests, so few of me -- who knows when I may be back?

question: My God! My God! Oh my God! Debbie rushes over to her.
answer: What's the matter?

question: My -- my ring. My diamond. I took it off in the ladies' room to wash my hands. I was just putting it on -- I must have dropped it.
answer: Let me help you, we'll find it.

question: Hey, what about our drinks? Tommy instantly assumes an ANGRY YOUNG STREET BLACK VOICE:
answer: Yeah? What you want?

question: What? You already took our order.
answer: That wasn't me! You must be thinking of Jamal. I'm Karim. What you want?

question: Bourbon straight up and a Perrier rocks.
answer: Hunh. He walks two steps...and once again makes no attempt to get the drinks. Zeke returns to Jeff Johnson.

question: I want every heating grate opened and inspected. I want every air conditioning duct vacuumed. Do you understand what I'm saying? AS he speaks, Bruno SEES Tommy pass through the hallway ... spot something on the floor... pick it up... furtive- ly put it in his pocket... and walk rapidly toward the door to the kitchens. Hey, you! Waiter! Hold it right there!
answer: No! Please! Do not report me! I will be deported!

question: Calm down. What've you got in your pocket?
answer: I told the CIA everything! I agreed to poison the pineapples! My green card is in the mail!

question: Stow it! I'm not Immigration, I'm hotel security. Now, what did you just put in your pocket?
answer: Nothing.

question: I'm warning you, flathead, get cute with me and I will tear you a second asshole. Now a valuable diamond ring is mising...
answer: Valuable? We can almost see the light bulb click on above Bruno's head.

question: Very valuable. All right, I'll give you a hunnert bucks for it.
answer: A hundred and five? Bruno snorts agreement, goes for his wallet... Tommy goes gor the ring... then suddenly leaps back in a cringe! No! It's a trick! You will call me a thief and send me back and the Security Police will make me stand on my head in the guano pit! I have seen such things on CNN! Bruno snaps and GRABS TOMMY BY THE COLLAR.

question: Jesus, I'm not trying to trick you...
answer: No, no... it is a trap! I must turn this over to police. He starts to leave. Bruno grabs him.

question: Listen, dipshit... a valuable ring is missing and there's thousands of dollars in reward money waiting. So you'd better fork over...
answer: How big is this... reward? Another lightbulb.

question: Um, five hundred dollars.
answer: You said 'thousands.'

question: Yeah. Right. A thousand dollars.
answer: No, no, no...you said thousands. With an 'S'. This is plural. This means "two or more thousands."

question: Okay, you win. Two thousand.
answer: Or more. Two or more. Bruno's had enough -- his grip tightens around Tommy's neck. Just making a point. 15 IN HOTEL LOBBY AT THE CASHIER'S DESK Bruno slides a 15 check to the Cashier, who counts a stack of bills. Bruno picks up a house phone, dials.

question: Olaf, there's something I wanted to sound you out on. As a special friend.
answer: Shoot. Tommy moves away from the pillar, sees Bruno roaming the terrace, and retreats.

question: I'm thinking of retiring from Congress. Andersen's eyes widen in astonishment.
answer: You're what?

question: I'm thinking maybe I won't run. Maybe I should listen more to this. Really appreciate these years. Sail around the world. Climb mountains. Enjoy the finer things of life.
answer: Jeff. Listen to me. You can't retire. Florida needs you. I need you. I need you on rates. I need you on regulations. I need you on those environmental nutcases --

question: Olaf, if I retire this year, I get to keep all the money left over in my campaign treasury. Comes to a very tidy nest-egg.
answer: How tidy?

question: One-point-three million. It's called the grandfather loophole. Bruno has gone. But Tommy stays. His eyes light up at the money.
answer: Come on, Jeff. Look at what you'd be giving up. Going to the best resorts in the world and calling it "official business." Golfing and skiing and fishing, and never picking up a tab. And, Jeff -- there's no aphrodisiac like power. You can have some of the most intelligent, attractive women in the country. You've got it made!

question: Oh, I suppose that one-point-three may seem like spare change to the head of Gulf Coast Power, but to a country boy like me --
answer: Okay, Jeff. I get it. Look. There's a little software company that's about to go through the roof. Johnson smiles at the direction the conversation is taking. ON Tommy also smiling, in admiration at the transaction going down. A few thousand worth of stock options would stand to make you quite a pile. As long as your blind trust buys them, you're clean -- the SEC can't shake a stick at you. Half a million, easy -- and that's just a start.

question: It was my honor to serve in Congress with Jeff Johnson for a generation. No one could have been a better legislator. No one could have been a finer husband and father. And now -- He presses the tips of his fingers together and looks skyward, as if communing with his memory of the deceased. And now God has called his servant home. ANGLE ON Jennifer, in black. We will miss him. But we are grateful that his passing was so peaceful -- and so like him -- working late into the night at his desk, the consummate public servant. Vera, I know you're still in shock from Jeff's... passing. But we have to talk about his seat. Vera stares at Jennifer. She knows the score. Vera, I'd like you to announce that you're going to run for Congress. Let a few days pass to show proper respect. But next week, I want to stand next to you at a press conference where you declare for Jeff's seat in the House.
answer: No, Dick -- no.

question: There's nothing to be afraid of, Vera. With your name, you can't lose. People around these parts are so used to voting for Jeff Johnson -- why, Mrs. Jeff Johnson would win in a walk.
answer: Dick, I was a Washington wife for twenty years. Twenty years of Potomac bullshit is plenty for one lifetime.

question: Vera, we're talking about becoming a Member of Congress. We're talking about a sure thing.
answer: I'm sure you would, dear. But I couldn't give you the same job satisfaction Jeff gave you. Jennifer, embarrassed, didn't know Vera knew. Nor did Dodge.

question: This is very sweet of you, darling. But you shouldn't have done it. Where did you get the money?
answer: You don't want to know.

question: How did I end up with a thief for a grandson?
answer: Grandma -- I told you. I'm not a thief. I'm a con man. An artist.

question: But also a crook.
answer: But I only con crooks, Grandma. You can't con an honest man. Only somebody who wants something for nothing. But the good Lord must have been fond of pigeons, because he made so many of them.

question: Sometimes I just wish you were more like your Daddy...
answer: You mean, dead?

question: Ja, this is Inga. Hello Paul... how are you tonight? You are feeling naughty? That's all right ...you have your what in a bowl of oatmeal? Yes, that is very naughty, and maybe a little sick.
answer: Disgusting.

question: Oh NO! It's my husband Lars. He's home early, I must go before ...you want to talk to Lars too? So you like to talk dirty out of both sides of your mouth. Man, you are one twisted bastard! Laughing, he hangs up.
answer: Tommy, please!

question: What did you say, Grandma? Homer! Get your ass over here!
answer: What's this about, jefe?

question: Loretta! Get off the damn phone!
answer: This better be good.

question: You people got a better idea?
answer: I do.

question: Okay... gimme the four-one-one on these Silver Foxes Again. It's a bunch of old folks who like to vote?
answer: Don't laugh, they get an enormous turnout. But the big thing is, they have their own line on the ballot. They already got the signatures.

question: Ah.
answer: The lady we're meeting, Hattie Rifkin, they call her the condo queen.

question: Oh, the usual sacrifical lamb. Probably Sylvia Roland. She just lost her husband, she needs to meet new people. Why?
answer: Mrs. Rifkin... I want to run.

question: Well, I want to run too -- but with this plastic hip, it's not gonna happen. Tommy breaks up. In spite of himself, he's charmed by the salty old babe.
answer: What I mean is... I'd like to run for Congress on the Silver Fox ticket. I care about you and your issues.

question: Yeah, that's what my son says. But does he call? Anyway, what makes you think a group of alter cockers are gonna support a man who hasn't clipped his first nose hair yet?
answer: Because I can win.

question: No, no... a Democrat can win. A Republican can win. A Silver Fox can only make a symbolic point.
answer: Mrs. RIfkin, if you give me a ballot line, and if I can get support from...

question: If... if. Ven die bubbah halla tsehen qulishkes, het gehaya zadeh.
answer: Sure, but... besser die viller ein der kenner. Hattie cracks up. Tommy leans over and translates for Van Dyke: She said, 'If my grandmother had balls, she'd be my grandfather.'

question: Where the Hell did you learn to speak Yiddish?
answer: The same place I learned to hustle shtarkers at gin rummy. From Morris Elfbein... the Gin King of Miami Beach.

question: No kidding... you knew the Rudolf Valentino of Dade County?
answer: He taught me a great deal. He taught me you don't always need the best cards to win.

question: Maybe not in gin, but in politics, young man, you need money to win, you need a name to win, you...
answer: Oh, I have a name.

question: What, you're an athlete, a movie star? I don't get out as much as I used to. You're not on MTV, are you?
answer: No ma'am. My name is Johnson. Jeff Johnson. The Name You Know.

question: Jeff Johnson. Well, that's a name even our Alzheimer's Group will remember. Still, for a full-up campaign, we'd need materials, we'd need ads...
answer: You leave that to me, Mrs. R.

question: You leave that to me, Mrs. R.
answer: I'm not sure I understand, Professor Franklin -- you wrote your doctoral thesis on my husband?

question: He was a great man, Mrs. Johnson. He did so much for my people.
answer: He... did?

question: Oh, yes. I'll never forget when he said 'Welfare is a drug -- and you gotta kick it cold turkey.' It was... inspirational.
answer: Really... well, I'm sure...

question: And I was actually in the audience when he said, 'If you people would just get off your dead asses and look for work, this country might be fit to live in again.' Powerful stuff.
answer: It's very kind of you to say so. And you're very kind to come all the way from... where was it?

question: Wilson-Pickett State Teachers College. But I didn't just come to pay respects, ma'am. I came because your husband deserves an archive. A place where scholars can study his legacy. A storehouse for the record of his remarkable career.
answer: I see. So you want... his papers?

question: Oh, not just his papers, Mrs. Johnson. Everything. Buttons, posters, bumper stickers. All the paraphernalia of his campaigns -- proof of his political genius. Now I realize that you may have a sentimental attachment to a few items...
answer: Take 'em.

question: I beg your pardon.
answer: Take 'em all. Would you like the wedding photos, too?

question: Well, I don't think that's necess...
answer: Good -- that way you won't have to go rooting around in the garbage. Is there anything else?

question: Well, um... no.
answer: More tea? Or something stronger? I know it's only ten-thirty, but, hell, sun's over the yardarm somewhere, right?

question: Actually, ma'am, I should be getting back.
answer: You're in pretty good shape for a professor. D'you work out? Tommy rises and packs his briefcase hastily.

question: We ran a positive campaign. We campaigned on the issues. The issue is leadership. Leadership for the future. Ask not what you can do for your country. The people have spoken. The only thing we have to fear is fear itself. If you can't stand the heat stay out of the kitchen. Live Free or Die. And in conclusion...read my lips! The promised land.
answer: Arthur Reinhardt. You remember me -- I Fed-Exed that material to you in Key West?

question: Reinhardt, my man! Of course! You look just like I pictured you. Nice wing tips.
answer: Thank you. Congressman, I hope you don't think I'm out of line for meeting you here -- I thought you might want some help with logistics, settling in at your hotel -- Since you didn't make it to the Harvard seminar, I put together a set of their papers for you.

question: I like your initiative, Reinhardt, but to tell you the truth, I've never been much of a student. Maybe you can brief my staff sometime. Reinhardt looks Tommy's cronies over. Not your classic Hill types. But thank you, I will take you up on those logistics. Hey! Entourage! What hotel we at? Reinhardt, it appears that the staff has neglected to nail down some details.
answer: Oh, Jesus, the IMF's in town. Where are we going to find a room?

question: Four rooms.
answer: I got lucky at the Madison. Thank god there's been a coup in Uruguay. Their delegation just checked out.

question: You're a wizard, Reinhardt. I knew you could handle it. So when does the House open for business? Reinhardt hasn't heard it put quite that way before. Reinhardt gets his courage up.
answer: Say, Congressman, you got my resume, didn't you?

question: I'm sure I did.
answer: There's something I wanted to ask you. I know it's a big step, but -- I'd like you to consider me to be your AA.

question: That's quite an offer, Reinhardt, very decent of you, but I'm just a social drinker.
answer: No. AA. Your Administrative Assistant. I worked for Congressman Johnson. I'd like to work for you, Congressman Johnson.

question: Really. Tommy looks at his own troops, then back to Reinhardt. You mean like an affirmative action thing? Tommy opens the cab door. Tell you what -- I'll think about it, okay? Tommy gets in and closes the door. Thanks for getting us settled, really appreciate it. Madison Hotel. That's okay, they're with me. Sixth floor please. Cannon 609. I'm going to my office. I am a Member. Now take us to six before I haul your ass in front of the committee on disrespectful behavior. Wait here. He heads further into the office. You again!
answer: Good morning, congressman.

question: What is this shithole?
answer: Excuse me?

question: This.
answer: Oh -- you missed the freshman lottery for offices. They assign them by draw. You didn't show for the draw, so you got the worst office in Congress.

question: I missed what lottery?
answer: It was all in the briefing books I mailed you.

question: What else did I miss, Reinhardt?
answer: Are you hiring me, congressman? Tommy gives Reinhardt a good once-over, seeing him anew.

question: You're shaking me down, aren't you? Tommy laughs, then clasps Reinhardt's shoulders. This is fantastic, Reinhardt. I haven't been here five minutes, and you're shaking me down. God, I'm gonna love this town. You're hired, man. Just tell me what to do next. I don't want to miss out on any of the good shit.
answer: The dinner for new Members is tonight, at Union Station. Do you have black tie? BEGIN elegant, spirited classical MUSIC.

question: Fine, but I'm gonna be real offended if either of you miss my reception. They leave. I think we have to have a reception. AT THE BUFFET, as Tommy and Loretta help themselves generously to oysters and champagne, they overhear TWO MEMBERS passing by. We're in the majors, doll. 62A THE BALCONY is full of people working one another. As 62A Tommy and Loretta pass some large stone statues, a man extends his hand -- liquor lobbyist KEN KORNGOLD.
answer: Congressman? I'd like to introduce myself. Ken Korngold. National Distilled Spirits Association.

question: Tommy Johnson. Distilled Spirits, is that right?
answer: It's super that you won, congressman. Any way we can help, please don't hesitate.

question: Pleasure's all mine, Ken, hope you can make it to my reception. Do you happen to have a card?
answer: I sure do.

question: You now what I love about this place? The way everyone calls you a Member. Every time I hear that, it makes me think of Mr. Happy here. Don't you be peeing on my shoe. They go to the sinks. The Member introduces himself.
answer: Mike Strangland. Iowa -- first CD.

question: You got a CD? Shit, I missed that, too.
answer: First Congressional district.

question: Ohhh. Tommy Johnson. Florida. So Iowa -- how'd you get to Washington? You do the crop report on tv? IOWA has a big open face and a flat Midwestern voice.
answer: No -- I owe it all to the Vietnamese.

question: War hero?
answer: P.O.W. When I got back to Cedar Rapids, I spent so many years telling the Rotary Club what was wrong in Washington, they finally told me to put up or shut up -- so I put up. And here I am.

question: Wait a minute. What's wrong in Washington?
answer: C'mon -- there's acid rain killing fish, and no one's stopping it... there's topsoil washing away, and no erosion program... there's chemicals in our livestock -- God, I sound like a Boy Scout.

question: That's alright, Iowa -- this place could use a few geeks like you. Hey... thank you... nice to see you... hope you can make it to my reception. Have y'all met Miss Loretta? TOMMY'S TABLEMATE is lawyer-lobbyist TOMMY O'CONNOR, 40s. As Waiters serve lobster bisque, he hands TJ a business card.
answer: Tommy O'Connor. Soon as I saw how you got elected, I knew you were a real comer. Hell, I bet old Olaf Andersen voted for you.

question: Who's Olaf Andersen?
answer: I won't tell him you asked. Chairman of Gulf Coast Power. Constituent of yours, client of mine. Pays the rent, know what I mean? Say, could I host a little welcome- to-Washington thing for you down at my law firm? Meet some of my clients, five hundred a head -- you could pick up twenty, twenty-five grand to get you started.

question: And how much of that do you get?
answer: Oh, it doesn't come off the top. Down the road, I'll bill 'em each five hundred an hour whenever I take you to lunch.

question: How do you do? You could make up for it by having a nightcap with me. May I have my car take you home?
answer: Excuse me, Mr. Chairman, but this ain't no homo shit we up to, is it?

question: No. No, it's not. But -- Good thinking, Johnson. I'm impressed by your instincts. Tell me, Johnson. Why did you come to Washington?
answer: Well... of course... it's a chance to do something for my country. I mean, there's the topsoil thing, and acid rain is killing the cattle --

question: Cut the bullshit, Johnson. I saw how you got elected. Flukes like you are either nutcases or troublemakers. I just want to know which one I have on my hands. Who sent you here?
answer: No one sent me.

question: You pulled off that upset on your own?
answer: Kid's got his talents.

question: I'm impressed, Johnson, I am. But why did you run for Congress?
answer: No bullshit?

question: No bullshit.
answer: Opportunity knocks. This town is the fuckin' Yukon. A stunned silence from Dodge -- then deep and generous laughter.

question: What a refreshing answer. He laughs again, richly amused. Tommy joins in the laughter.
answer: Food... drinks.

question: You're on cheese. I'll handle booze. He reaches for the phone... Ken! Ken Korngold! Tommy Johnson here... Right -- last night. How's it going, big guy?
answer: Congressman! How are you on this helluva fine day! I'm looking forward to your reception.

question: Actually, that's why I'm calling, Ken. You said if I needed some help --
answer: You name it, congressman. Issue papers, testimony, floor speeches --

question: Tell you what I have in mind. I was just thinking, wouldn't it be a plus for old Ken Korngold if I was to -- how should I put this -- showcase some of his distillers' products at my reception? You know, like they put Reese's pieces in E.T.? It's called "product placement." People come in, they have a tremendous time, they see your products, they think well of you -- and they think well of me, too. It's good for both of us, Ken. What do you say?
answer: Well, it's a new one on me, but hey, sure, I think we can help you out. Say, while I have you on the line, there was one thing...

question: Oh, that's just wonderful. Sixty heavy hitters drop in, and I'm feeding 'em cat food. He breaks off, as Celia comes into view in the doorway behind. Tommy picks her up on his radar. We'll talk about this later. We follow Tommy through the crowd until he reaches Celia. Hi there. Glad you could make it. So you're... Celia Kirby. That's an extremely beautiful name. For an extremely beautiful woman.
answer: Wow! That's smooth. After ten straight hours on my feet making small talk and breathing cheap cigar smoke, that's exactly the kind of line I'm ready to fall for.

question: Whoa, slow down.
answer: Sure, sure, forget it. Can you just tell me, which one's Congressman Johnson?

question: What if I said... me?
answer: Oh. I see. So tell me, Congressman, just how deep is the shit I'm standing in? Tommy has to laugh.

question: Don't worry about it. Why don't we just start over again?
answer: Celia Kirby. I'm the legislative director of Pro Bono.

question: Ah. Pro Bon. That's an extremely beautiful name. For an extremely beautiful organization. Um... what is it?
answer: We're a public interest research and advocacy group. I'd like to brief you on our priorities this session. Can I call your AA to get on your schedule?

question: Why don't you brief me over dinner tonight?
answer: I want an appointment, Congressman, not a date.

question: Yeah, sure, we'll type it up on the schedule, it'll be an appointment, except with wine and flowers on the table.
answer: No thanks. I really should be going.

question: Won't you at least stay for a drink and some herring?
answer: I'm afraid I'm busy.

question: Well then, can I tempt you with a smelt?
answer: No thanks. Nice to meet you. I'll be in touch with your office. I especially look forward to hearing your view on extending the sexual harassment law to include congressmen.

question: I heard in the steam room you're going to try to screw up my ethics bill.
answer: Not screw up. Amend.

question: Come on, Eli, your amendments don't have a chance in hell to pass. My bill isn't perfect, I know, but it'll pass. And the President'll sign it.
answer: "Isn't perfect"? Dick, your bill's the Incumbents Protection Act! How can you even call it an ethics bill?

question: Because the public wants an ethics bill! So that's what we call it.
answer: But it's got no teeth! It won't change a thing, and you know it.

question: Come on, Eli, you're a politician, too. The less you're going to do about something, the more you have to talk about it. You know that. They start walking.
answer: I see. We close the bank, we stop the rubber checks, we raise the prices in the barber shop, we stop fixing parking tickets, and abracadabra! We say we've cleaned up Congress. Well, I don't think the American people want what this place has become.

question: That's the beauty of it! They must, Eli -- they keep re-electing us.
answer: Not anymore! This new Congress is full of new faces.

question: Oh, I wouldn't read too much into that. A few extra retirements, some redistricting -- nothing more than that. It's still business as usual up here. Dodge takes his glasses from his pocket and wipes them. I live in the real world, Eli. Do you? What's unemployment up to in your district? Eight percent? Eight-five?
answer: Eight point six.

question: Power and Enterprise is about to fund a solar demonstration plant, Eli. It could mean a whole lot to a district -- new jobs, new construction -- that interest you?
answer: You can't bribe me, Dick.

question: Eli, the people who elected you. They sent you here to help them. Don't you want to?
answer: Not if it means supporting your bill. All you want is the perfect platform to campaign for Speaker. Dick Dodge. Mr. Clean. What a joke!

question: Come on board, Eli. You know -- you can't save the world if you can't save your seat. Tommy enters. Marshall gives him a once-over and extends a hand.
answer: We haven't met. Eli Marshall.

question: We haven't met. Eli Marshall.
answer: Tommy Johnson.

question: I know. The Florida upset. Well, now that you're here, what are you going to do with it? You gonna feather your own nest, or are you gonna make something of your office?
answer: I plan to be as good a congressman as all the others.

question: Exactly what does that mean?
answer: Well, ever since I got back from Nam, I've wanted to do something about the rain forest --

question: Eli, you'll excuse us -- we have a meeting. Johnson, I'm the chairman of a committee up here called Power and Industry. We've got an open seat, and I was wondering if you'd consider filling it.
answer: Is this good news?

question: Well, it is a difficult assignment -- look at what we cover
answer: So... this is very good news.

question: Most members would give their right nut for it.
answer: So what do you want from me, Dick?

question: So, Congressman, welcome to the honey pot. You should be one happy freshman.
answer: Yeah? Well, I'm not. I'm suspicious. One thing I've learned is, when somebody gives you something for nothing, the nothing ain't nothing. It's something. What is it? Why me? Reinhardt puts his hand on Tommy's shoulders.

question: Congressman, I don't want you to take this the wrong way, but... you're black. And I mean that in the nicest possible way.
answer: Keep talking.

question: Pleased to meet you, Barclay. WARBURTON'S voice is aristocratic, a la George Plimpton.
answer: Skeeter. Please. Been called that since boarding school.

question: Skeeter.
answer: Damned fine to meet you. As Dodge and Tommy head for the dais, Tommy imitates Warburton's lockjaw.

question: Let me start with a confession. I don't know much about poultry. But I do know something about people. And let me tell you My man. He blows a kiss to a pretty Teller in the credit union. Passing the barber shop, he calls out to the Shoeshine Guy. He passes a black TELEPHONE MAN at an open panel of wires. Sweet Sue. Third race at Santa Anita. Hey, how you folks doin', good to see you, Van Dyke making you comfortable? Tommy hits a button on a tape deck, turning on some EASY Be with y'all shortly. BEHIND THE DIVIDER, outside Tommy's office door, Tommy has a word with Reinhardt. Tommy indicates his office. She in there? Reinhardt nods. Tommy gives himself a couple of squirts of Binaca. Stick around for this, Reinhardt. I've finally figured something out about the women in this town.
answer: Thank you for seeing us, congressman, we won't take up much of your time. This is Ira Schecter, our research director. But you have people waiting, and --

question: That's all right. They can wait.
answer: Well. She pulls documents from her briefcase and hands them to Tommy. These are issue papers. This session we're targeting auto insurance premiums, child safety, and food additives. As votes come up, we know you'll be hearing plenty from the other side. We'd just like a clean shot at making our case, too. So, we'll follow up with your staff in the next week or...

question: Wait a minute, you just got here. I clean my calendar, and you're out the door. Let's back up, give this stuff the attention it deserves. Car insurance... Ira, what do you pay?
answer: Oh, I've got an '85 Plymouth, about six-fifty a year...

question: Six-fifty? Highway robbery! A chop shop wouldn't give you more than a hundred forty for a junker like that. Or so I've heard. But I'm flying blind here, I need depth. Could Miss Kirby put together a briefing? Maybe schedule a Saturday or two to really dig into the issues?
answer: Oh... we'd be delighted. We've got some figures that will amaze you.

question: I'm sure you do.
answer: Well, we won't take up any more...

question: Whoa, whoa, hold on, what about child safety?
answer: Well, we're sponsoring a bill imposing safety standards on imported toys...

question: Let's get serious, fellas. 93 INT. CATACOMBS - NIGHT 93 Tommy, Marshall, and the Bulldog, back in suits, exit the MEMBERS ONLY door and move through the catacombs.
answer: I need your help on the ethics bill, Leon. I want you to co- sponsor my amendments. That wasn't a yes. He took six hundred dollars off you that last hand, didn't he?

question: Yeah, he's taking a real shine to me.
answer: If I didn't know better, I'd say you lost to him on purpose.

question: Nothing wrong with letting the chairman of the ethics committee roll you once in a while.
answer: You fit in real well up here. Too well.

question: So Eli, how come you haven't asked for my help with your amendments?
answer: Give it a rest, Tommy. You've got a great jump shot. But everyone knows you're Dick Dodge's boy.

question: I'm nobody's boy, mister.
answer: Don't waste your outrage on me. I know what you are.

question: I'm no different from anyone else.
answer: That's not true. Some people here actually try to do something besides save their own ass.

question: You know, Eli, I like you, I really do. You remind me of my father.
answer: Oh, really? How so?

question: He thought I was scum, too. BELLS begin RINGING and LIGHTS FLASHING on all the clocks and sconces down the corridor. Three RINGS, pause, three RINGS, pause... Marshall does a U-turn. Tommy doesn't follow suit.
answer: Aren't you going to vote?

question: You're in excellent hands, kids.
answer: You're a gentleman, Tommy. We can always do bid'ness -- I like that in a Member.

question: Thank you, Tommy. I love you too.
answer: Listen, I'd like to do more money for you -- I just need to know your positions on a few issues. O'Connor takes out a pen and leather notecard case. For instance, where are you on sugar price supports?

question: Sugar price supports. Where do you think I should be, Tommy?
answer: Shit -- makes no difference to me. If you're for 'em, I got money for you from my sugar producers in Louisiana and Hawaii. If you're against 'em, I got money for you from the candy manufacturers.

question: You pick.
answer: Let's put you down as for. Now what about putting limits on malpractice awards?

question: You tell me.
answer: Well, if you're for 'em, I got money from the doctors and insurance companies. If you're against 'em, I got money from the trial lawyers. Tell you what, let's say against. Now how about pizza?

question: I'll stick with the salad.
answer: Not for lunch, shmuck, for PAC money. A lot of the frozen pizzas use phony cheese. There's a law pending requiring them to disclose it on their labels. Where do you stand? Tommy thinks it through.

question: If I vote for the labels...then I get money from the dairy industry...
answer: Good...

question: And if I vote against the labels, I get money from the frozen food guys.
answer: Excellent! And don't forget the ranchers, because they get hurt if pepperoni sales go down!

question: A pepperoni lobby. I love this town.
answer: So which is it?

question: Fuck the cheese people. Thanks to them my office smelled like smelt for a week.
answer: All right. For.

question: So Tommy, tell me -- with all this money on every side, how does anything get done?
answer: It doesn't! That's the genius of the system!

question: ...And in the 1988 study, it was up to eight per hundred-thousand. Um...am I losing you on these mortality rates?
answer: No, I was just wondering how much of this is a statutory problem, and how much is a regulatory one? I mean, didn't the Merton Act cover most of this?

question: Hmmm, that's an excellent point. Let me see something... As she starts rummaging in her briefcase, we TRACK AROUND to a COMPUTER SCREEN on Tommy's desk -- it displays THE Wow...you're right. Maybe we can get them to amend Merton-Simmons. RACK FOCUS...reveals REINHARDT in b.g., sitting at another computer terminal. He is typing in Tommy's responses, which appear on Tommy's screen.
answer: Well, for Merton to apply you have to show high contagion...sounds to me like your contagion rates are no higher than the common clod. In b.g., Reinhardt DIVES FORWARD to his keyboard and begins correcting his typo. Celia looks puzzled. Common cold. Must have picked up a little dyslexia over the weekend.

question: I see. Well, I must say I'm pretty impressed.
answer: You're also impressively pretty.

question: Oh come on...
answer: You're right. Sorry. Excuse me a second. Arthur? Without explanation, he THROWS HIS PENCIL hard out of frame.

question: Must have had a heart attack. Did you miss me?
answer: Where did you go?

question: Oh, a fact-finding mission, some issue conferences, a few speaking engagements, a charity event... the usual.
answer: More like the Petroleum Institute Ski Cup, the NRA Open, the --

question: Hey. Have lunch with me tomorrow.
answer: I can't -- we're having a press conference.

question: What is it -- the ozone layer? No fault? Killer apples?
answer: Toy safety. Wait a minute. Tomorrow's Friday. Aren't you back early?

question: You remembered! That means you missed me. So, how'd you end up hustling for Pro Bono instead of pesticides? I mean, you could have been a big- time lawyer, right?
answer: Oh, I was for a while. It... depressed me.

question: At a hundred grand a year, how depressed can you get? Doesn't it depress you to lose all the time?
answer: Sometimes. Mostly it gets me angry. And the anger keeps me going. Sure, I wouldn't mind winning a few. And it's not like I'm allergic to money...

question: So why do you do it? She skips a stone on the water.
answer: God, it's so embarrassing to come out and say it.

question: Say it.
answer: Meaning. I need my life to mean something. My question is, how'd you get named after a Memorial?

question: Grandma like Jefferson. Y'know, "Life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness." It's a lot to live up to, so I specialized in the last part.
answer: And how's the pursuit going?

question: Fine...'til I met you. Now...the better I do, the worse I feel. They have stopped walking. They are standing close together. They kiss. So...when can I see you again? How about dinner Saturday night? She shakes her head.
answer: How about Sunday morning?

question: Uncle Eli?
answer: My niece says you're not half as slimy as I thought.

question: Your niece?
answer: That would put you somewhere between a lizard and a toad. Quite a step up. Tommy looks from Marshall to Celia and back again.

question: Now let me get this straight. You voted to make people on Medicare pay more money to their doctors?
answer: The Medical Association made a persuasive case. Ten grand from their PAC, plus Christmas in Aspen.

question: Tommy -- if I'm not mistaken, you wouldn't be here without the good senior citizens of your district. You got to dance with the girl that brung you, son. If you have a bit of business to do, do it quietly... in the corridors... in the subcommittees... with little amendments. You mess around on the big ones like Medicare, you'll be dead meat on election day.
answer: Yeah, well, then it's thanks for the memories, and on to the next gig.

question: Do you know what your problem is, son? You don't think big enough. You have a real knack for this town, but you have the soul of a two-bit hustler. Listen to me, Tommy. Five hundred thirty-five Members of Congress. Some are smart, and some stupid. Some good, some not. But all of them, son, all of them consumed by the single overriding imperative that defines the very Washington way of life.
answer: Which is?

question: Getting re-elected.
answer: Wait a minute. You're talkin' 'bout my re-election?

question: You don't know what percent of the incumbents who ran last time got re-elected, do you?
answer: Fifty? Sixty?

question: Ninety-six. And ninety-eight before that. It's like that election after election. If you don't fuck up, you can be here, raking it in, for life. Life, Johnson. Tommy considers this. Then a big smile.
answer: I can think of worse places to get life.

question: I knew you had it in you.
answer: So how do I get the Silver Foxes off my ass?

question: Oh, throw them a bone... why don't you co-sponsor a bill for mandatory universal health insurance?
answer: What's that mean?

question: Five children in the neighborhood have cancer. One more has precancerous lesions. Pregnant women around here are scared to death.
answer: This is Mickey's school?

question: Turns out a lot of schools are near power lines. The land's cheap, so the schools tend to buy it from the power companies in the first place.
answer: But isn't the school district responsible?

question: We asked the superintendent to measure the magnetic field inside the school. He said, Okay, only it'll cost forty thousand dollars, and what program did we want him to cut that from?
answer: Nice.

question: We're nobody, congressman. You're somebody. We need your help. Tommy takes Celia aside.
answer: Do you believe it?

question: Do you believe it?
answer: It's impossible to know. No one's really looked into it hard enough.

question: But why isn't it being investigated?
answer: Why didn't they investigate breast implants all those years? What about those side-effects of that sleeping pill, Halcion? Why isn't anything being investigated? It's always the same.

question: Money talks.
answer: You got it.

question: There must be something I can do for those people.
answer: Don't tell me you're actually developing a conscience.

question: Shit, I hope not -- it'd be a fucking nuisance in Congress.
answer: No, that's not fair. Some people on the Hill actually believe in things, and try to do a decent job, and don't forget why they went to Washington, and who sent them.

question: No shit. Oh, yeah, I met one of those geeks. So what can I do?
answer: Make a stink. Round up some Members and hold a press conference. Get that committee of yours to hold hearings. Haul in in the Environmental Protection Agency, the Surgeon General, the National Academy of Sciences. Get the issue on every breakfast table in America.

question: Speaking of hopeless causes... They kiss, and slide OUT OF FRAME.
answer: On the rocks, or neat?

question: Whatever you're having.
answer: Well, why ruin good bourbon with the taste of some shitty Sears icemaker, that's what I always say. Cheers.

question: Cheers. Dodge downs his drink. Tommy follows suit.
answer: Son, you're a real comer. I wouldn't be surprised if you ended up in the leadership. I'll say this

question: Why, thank you, Mr. Chairman. You know, to tell you the truth, I didn't know you'd be on my side on those power lines.
answer: But I'm not.

question: But you said you were sympathetic --
answer: Of course I did. We're all sympathetic to little girls with cancer. But I'm not sympathetic to holding an inquiry.

question: But you said --
answer: I know what I said. But that was just a press conference, son. I wasn't under oath. The intercom BUZZES. Yes?... Bring them right in! Look. Son. It's great to get your name in the paper. I bet the gentleman from Iowa was all over the evening news in Des Moines tonight. Getting good press -- letting them know you care -- that's what it's all about. Smart move, Tommy. But that's as far as I'd go with this, if I were you. The door opens. Dodge turns to see Olaf Anderson, Tommy O'Connor, and Zeke Bridges enter. What a surprise!

question: Tommy and I were just talking about power lines.
answer: Yeah, what a coincidence. I thought this little party might be for me. You may not like this. I think we should hold those hearings.

question: You really fell for the line that parents group fed you, didn't you? Tommy is struck by Dodge's intelligence.
answer: How'd you know I met the parents group?

question: Mmmm...
answer: Mmmm...

question: So what did he say?
answer: Who?

question: Dodge. The hearings.
answer: Oh -- I, uh, haven't asked him yet. It wasn't the right moment. Besides, I was thinking, maybe I ought to line up some other Members first -- you know, get my ducks in a row.

question: You see that ABC poll? President in trouble like that, he's liable to do something desperate. Some damn fool stunt.
answer: You shafted me on the ethics bill.

question: Hello, Eli, good to see you. Why don't you loosen your tie?
answer: It's a closed rule. I can't get my amendments on the floor. I can't get a recorded vote. I can't get squat.

question: Last time I looked, it was the Rules Committee in charge of that. This isn't the Rules Committee, Eli. This is the steam room.
answer: This is the U.S. Congress! The American people deserve better than --

question: You know what your problem is, Eli? You've got sermonitis. The other Members chuckle. Can't open your mouth without climbing into the pulpit, can you? Why don't you just calm down, have a massage --
answer: I've got news for you, Dick. I'm going to run against you for Speaker. I may not have a rat's ass of a chance to beat you. But I sure as hell can tell the world the kind of sleaze you stand for.

question: I went too far with him, I know it. You know him pretty well, don't you?
answer: Oh, I don't know...

question: Come on, you play basketball together, you're seeing his niece, you've been to his church --
answer: How did you know that?

question: He'll listen to you, Tommy. I want you to go make peace between us. Tell him we'll work something out on his amendments -- not a vote, I won't go that far, but at least he'll get to say his piece on the floor. Just get him off my back. Can you do that for me?
answer: That's not a question, is it?

question: That's right. Is there a problem?
answer: No, no -- I've still got my right nut, I can work with that. Sure, why not. Marshall takes a boiled crab from the platter between them, places it on the butcher paper in front of him, christens it --

question: No, no -- I've still got my right nut, I can work with that. Sure, why not. Marshall takes a boiled crab from the platter between them, places it on the butcher paper in front of him, christens it --
answer: The honorable Dick Dodge. -- raises a big wooden mallet, and SMASHES it on the crab, smiling.

question: You know, Eli, sometimes people do things they regret. Everyone makes mistakes. Fact is, Dick's been under a lot of pressure lately --
answer: That man's a walking quid quo pro -- prid quo -- quid pro quo, and you know it. He put you up to this, didn't he?

question: What do you mean?
answer: Don't shit me, Tommy. You're Dick Dodge's yes-man. I know what you're up to. This is damage control.

question: I'm not a yes-man. When Dick says no, I say no. Marshall SMASHES down again with the mallet. Crab carnage.
answer: You know why no one on the Hill drops a dime on anyone else? Mutual assured destruction. Our little gentleman's agreement. Everybody has something on somebody, so nobody has anything on anybody, because everybody wants to save his own ass.

question: Oh, yeah? What do they have on you?
answer: They think I'm a pompous ass.

question: Loretta! Please! Your mouth! I need an ambulance right away. Evening, Mrs. Dodge, Tommy Johnson here, sorry to call at this hour, is Dick back from the Gridiron dinner yet? Could I speak with him for just a moment?
answer: What's wrong? INTERCUT Tommy and Dodge.

question: How did you know?
answer: Good news doesn't come at this hour.

question: I went out with Marshall. We got into an accident. He's out cold. I'm okay.
answer: Were you driving?

question: No. Someone else. Loretta. Dodge recovers his equilibrium.
answer: The girl from your office?

question: Yeah. She's out, too. I don't like the way it looks. For anybody. Look. You said you wanted to get back into Marshall's good graces. Well, here's an opportunity.
answer: Listen carefully. Tell the ambulance to take you to Walter Reed. It's a privilege they give congressmen. It's also the only hospital without a bunch of goddam reporters shtupping the nurses in exchange for leaks. They'll keep it quiet. I'll handle the police. You go home and keep your mouth shut.

question: Oh sweet Jesus.
answer: Get away from him. He approaches her. And get away from me.

question: I have to talk to you.
answer: Go away!

question: I was set up!
answer: You were set up? You were in the car! I didn't hear your name on the news!

question: No, someone screwed him --
answer: "Someone"?

question: Celia, something stinks here --
answer: Yeah -- it's you! You don't give a damn about anything! And to think, the other night, I actually thought you cared about someone else. Not me, you jerk -- Mickey Juba! You caved on those power lines, didn't you? I knew it. Damn it, I knew it! What did you get for it? Tommy O'Connor's box at the Redskins? Someone slip you a condo in the Virgin Islands?

question: If you'd give me a chance to --
answer: God, I hate this town -- the only reason I stay is because I hate it so much.

question: Celia --
answer: Get the hell out of here.

question: Is it thumb over, or thumb under?
answer: Under. She tries her hand at a false shuffle. Not bad, kid. You've got potential.

question: So what's happening? I thought you were going to kick some ass on -- She indicates the derricks. Tommy looks at her, comes to a decision.
answer: I am. He takes the deck from her, fans it face up, pulls all the kings and aces, stacks them on top, and squares the deck. This is one's called the double duke. How many players?

question: Six.
answer: Who's the mark?

question: Number two -- over there. Tommy, smiling, calculates something for a moment, then gives the deck four shuffles. He hands Mickey the cards.
answer: Your deal. She deals out six hands in a circle on the ground. Look at the sucker's hand. Look at your hand. She turns over her own hand. It has the four aces. Mickey looks at the power lines, at the hands, at TJ. Then, understanding:

question: That's what you're going to do? Tommy nods. Her face opens into a big smile. Let's kick some ass. What do I do?
answer: Something very important.

question: Right on the nose. He throws open the bay window of the narrow house. Just below is a pickup truck with "Homer's Pit Stop" lettered on the side. Homer gets out. My man! The others come to the window to see Homer, still wearing his fuel-smeared overalls, and SHOUT greetings. Now let's get to work. Eli Marshall caught his tail in a crack, didn't he?
answer: He did.

question: You kept my name out of it.
answer: I did.

question: I owe you one.
answer: You learn fast.

question: Do me one favor, Dick. Next time you pull some heavy shit involving my ass, tip me off, okay?
answer: Alright, son. This hearing of the Power and Enterprise Committee is now in order. The health of America's securities industry --

question: Mr. Yancey?
answer: I thought you'd be alone.

question: He's my AA. He goes where I go. If you can trust me, you can trust him. Homer eyes Reinhardt a moment, then continues.
answer: Congressman, I have information I think you may want. It's about something going on at the EPA.

question: What have you got?
answer: I got a wife and three kids, and a note on my house, that's what I got.

question: This stuff's pretty good?
answer: In the right hands, it could mean a great deal.

question: Okay. Sunday. Fifth race at Del Mar. Blueboy is running twenty to one. I'd take a major position.
answer: You have to be shitting me.

question: No, not at all -- my Cousin Henry spends his days pumping water into horses' stomachs and stuffing Percodan up their butts. Trust me. Reinhardt is interested in this. And he admires Tommy's m.o.
answer: Alright. The White House is putting heat on the EPA. They want us to announce a major investigation of the relation between power lines and cancer clusters.

question: Yeah, but when the draft got to the White House, they didn't like it. So they brought their own scientists in to kill it.
answer: Why did the White House change its mind?

question: Who knows?
answer: Is there new evidence?

question: Yeah -- their polls have dropped like a rock. They need an issue. This one makes them look good on the environment, and they don't have to spend a penny.
answer: And what good is this to me?

question: Got a minute, Dick? Tommy takes him aside. The room empties except for them. Listen, Dick, I heard something. There's got to be some bid'ness in it. Tommy very discreetly gestures with his thumb and palm Maybe we can go in on it together.
answer: I'm listening.

question: The EPA is going to make a stink about power lines. The White House is pushing them to do a big study.
answer: That's very interesting, my friend. I've heard that, too.

question: Nothing gets by, do it? Tommy touches his nose, in tribute to the master.
answer: But thank you, son -- I'm glad you chose to share it with me. We do make quite a team, don't we?

question: I -- I hope it wasn't my press conference that started this.
answer: No, this is a stunt for the polls.

question: So do you think there's something in it for us?
answer: If we got the EPA off Olaf Andersen's back, he'd be extremely appreciative.

question: And how do we do that?
answer: My committee writes the EPA's programs. We audit their funds. We confirm their appointees. I've got them by the balls.

question: And you're going to -- ? Tommy makes a squeezing gesture, grins.
answer: Oh, no, not at all -- just... persuasion. Strenuous persuasion.

question: That's allowed?
answer: Persuasion, yes. Intimidation, no. But it's a gray area. Who's to say which is which?

question: Dick, wait a minute -- shouldn't we check out the tip? Make sure the EPA's really going through with this investigation?
answer: Of course. He should be in by now.

question: Who?
answer: Skeeter Warburton, of course. Always go right to the top, son. Get me the EPA Administrator, please. 145 INT. CORRIDOR/STAIRWELL - CANNON - DAY 145 Tommy jogs along the corridor. A tourist Family stares at him. He explains his haste with a smile --

question: Warbuton here. Thank you. Mr. Chairman! I do hope there's something I can help you with today.
answer: I need a straight answer from you, Skeeter. Is the White House on your ass about power lines?

question: Off the record?
answer: Of course.

question: I was looking forward to some serious sailing this week -- Tish and I have a lovely spot right by Kennebunkport. Instead, here I am at three in the morning, writing testimony to your committee about cancer clusters.
answer: Thanks for your candor, Warburton.

question: Olaf? Olaf, Zeke Bridges. Listen, you sum' bitch, I'm so mad, I can't sit down to shit. Have you heard what I heard? INTERCUT with Andersen.
answer: What's that.

question: The EPA's fixing to make a big stink about power lines and cancer. They're going to serve us up for breakfast.
answer: Wait a minute. There's no scientific proof --

question: Proof don't mean shit. We're talking politics. They make a federal case out of power lines, I'm screwed. Whole insurance business is screwed. You know how much cash I'd have to pay out in settlements? Even if I stiffed everybody on claims, the legal fees'd be enough to kill me.
answer: I can't believe it.

question: Hi.
answer: Excuse me. She turns, starts to walk away. Tommy stops her.

question: Look. Whatever you think of me, just promise me one thing. She glares at him angrily. But then she's surprised to hear: Come to the Clean Air hearing tomorrow.
answer: What?

question: Power and Enterprise. Noon.
answer: But why? He gives her an enigmatic smile and slips away. As he rejoins Dodge, Tommy SEES WARBURTON enter the room. Alarmed, TOmmy moves in on Dodge, steering him to avoid the EPA Administrator.

question: Let's work the room just a bit more.
answer: Congressman! Mr. Chairman! As Dodge turns to see him --

question: Evening, Reinhardt. -- he SEES Warburton.
answer: Good to see you, sir. By the way, I thought your opening statement in committee yesterday was brilliant. Dodge points out Warburton to Tommy.

question: Well. Look who's over there -- Skeeter Warburton from the EPA. The very man we want to see.
answer: Have you tried the oysters, Dick?

question: At a hazardous waste event? I think we'll go talk to him.
answer: No, he's the wrong man --

question: You don't understand -- he's the perfect man.
answer: But -- but you don't want to bother him with this. Talk to one of his underlings -- Dodge looks at Tommy with curiosity, not understanding his reluctance.

question: Nothing beats man-to-man.
answer: Here? Not here!

question: A public place. What could be better?
answer: But it's the wrong time!

question: Come on, son, we've got the people's business to do. He leads Tommy off to one side. Reinhardt brings Warburton to them.
answer: Mr. Chairman. Congressman.

question: I've got a big problem, Skeeter.
answer: What's that?

question: Your power lines investigation.
answer: What power lines investigation? Tommy is sweating bullets.

question: We're off the record, Skeeter. This witch-hunt for cancer clusters is bad news for everyone.
answer: I don't know what you're talking about, Dick.

question: Alright, I know you're being a good soldier --
answer: No, I'm being straight with you --

question: Then let me be straight with you. You announce this study -- I'm not talking about the results down the road, mind you, I'm just talking about the announcement -- and there's broken crockery everywhere. Real estate. Utilities. Insurance. Schools. Local governments. It'll cost jobs. Uproot families.
answer: I agree with you completely. There isn't going to be an investigation, old chap, I promise you.

question: I'm glad we understand each other.
answer: Yes, I think we do. Tommy silently rejoices in his good fortune.

question: And we'll just forget about that phone call this morning?
answer: We didn't speak on the phone.

question: I want to do a little something nice for Dodge. That EPA thing -- he's been good to me, Reinhardt. Is there some way I can, like, throw a bouquet to him at the hearing today without having to sit through that boring testimony shit?
answer: Why don't you ask him to give you the floor at the start?

question: He's do that?
answer: For some flattery? In a New York minute. Just tip him ahead of time.

question: Good thinking. They return to the corridor. Tommy looks at his watch. Say, Reinhardt, my Grandma's plane comes in at ten. You wouldn't mind picking her up and driving Miss Daisy around, would you?
answer: Can't one of the others do it?

question: This meeting of the Power and Enterprise Committee to consider the reauthorization of the Clean Air Act is now in session. Today's first business is a panel of national leaders in the field of utilities. Before I welcome them, Chair would like to yield to the gentleman from Florida for a word. If there is no objection from the Committee -- ? The gentleman may proceed.
answer: Mr. Chairman, on behalf of the other members of this committee, and on behalf of myself, I have a very personal statement to make. From the bottom of my heart, I want to thank you -- thank you for your leadership, for your insight, for your boldness... Dodge preens for the cameras, until: ... and for your courage. Especially your courage.

question: My courage?
answer: Your courage in exposing the corruption that eats away at this institution. Your courage in taking on the special interests. Your courage in taking a major new step --

question: But I've... I've... I've done nothing new, nothing at all -- what are you talking about?
answer: You're right -- integrity isn't new to you, Mr. Chairman, it's second nature to you. Still it's a rare public servant who'll take on the special interest money, take on the PACs -- ANDERSEN, wary, senses danger. take on the lobbyists and fat cats -- CELIA is fascinated. ... and who'll stand up instead for ordinary American citizens... ... the plain people who just want peace of mind -- who just want to know they're raising their kids in safe neighborhoods and sending them to safe schools. ON THE DAIS Dodge wants to wrap this up. Yes, courage, Mr. Chairman, is a quality that you have in abundance --

question: Well, yes, thank you, but we have to move along, if the gentleman would --
answer: Ladies and gentlemen, yesterday, the Chairman and I had a meeting in his office with Olaf Andersen of Gulf Coast Power, and his lobbyist, Mr. Tommy O'Connor -- these gentlemen here. Chairman Dodge and I listened in astonishment as Olaf Andersen offered us seven figures -- that's one million dollars, ladies and gentlemen.
